spanishExample: ¡Haz eso! Esa es la idea por la que *we argued.*
englishTranslation: Do that! That is the idea because of which we argued.
vocabIncluded: "la que" to mean "which" after a preposition

spanishExample: ¡Hazlo! Ese fue el problema por el que no fuimos.
englishTranslation: Do it! That was the problem because of which we didn’t go.
vocabIncluded: "el que" to mean "which" after a preposition

spanishExample: ¿Cuál de los dos le *you gave* a tu amiga?
englishTranslation: Which of the two did you give to your friend(f)?
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: ¿Cuál es la razón por la que estamos aquí con ellos?
englishTranslation: What is the reason for which we are here with them?
vocabIncluded: "la que" to mean "which" after a preposition

spanishExample: El chico tiene razón.
englishTranslation: The boy is right.
vocabIncluded: tener razón: "to be right" (idiom, lit. "to have reason")

spanishExample: Esa es la razón por la que no estamos de acuerdo.
englishTranslation: That is the reason we do not agree.
vocabIncluded: "la que" to mean "which" after a preposition

spanishExample: Ese fue el acuerdo por el que *they fought.*
englishTranslation: That was the agreement because of which they fought.
vocabIncluded: "el que" to mean "which" after a preposition

spanishExample: Hacías ese trabajo y tenías buenas ideas.
englishTranslation: You used to do that job and you had good ideas.
vocabIncluded: hacías: "were doing/making", "you were doing/making" (Hacer, imperfect, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Le *I told* a mi amiga que tenía que tener mucho cuidado.
englishTranslation: I told my friend(f) that she had to be very careful.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
tener cuidado: "to be careful" (idiom, lit. "to have carefulness")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Le *I will tell* “hágalo” y él estará de acuerdo.
englishTranslation: I will tell him “do it(formal)” and he will agree.
vocabIncluded: estará: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Estar, future, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Lo harás cuando ellos lo hagan.
englishTranslation: You will do it when they do it.
vocabIncluded: harás: "will do/make", "you will do/make" (Hacer, future, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Lo haría con cuidado para tenerlo.
englishTranslation: I would do it carefully to have it.
vocabIncluded: haría: "would do/make", "I would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 1st person)
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: Me *he gave* una razón para hacerlo de esa forma.
englishTranslation: He gave me a reason to do it that way.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: Se lo *I told* a la chica porque de verdad lo haría.
englishTranslation: I told it(m) to the girl because I would really do it(m).
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
haría: "would do/make", "I would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Siempre *she wants* tener razón, así que se lo *I told.*
englishTranslation: She always wants to be right, so I told her it.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
tener razón: "to be right" (idiom, lit. "to have reason")

spanishExample: Siempre tienen mucho cuidado cuando hacen ese trabajo.
englishTranslation: They are always very careful when they do that job.
vocabIncluded: tener cuidado: "to be careful" (idiom, lit. "to have carefulness")

spanishExample: Tenemos que tener cuidado porque esa no es la mejor forma.
englishTranslation: We have to be careful because that is not the best way.
vocabIncluded: tener cuidado: "to be careful" (idiom, lit. "to have carefulness")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tenemos un acuerdo, los dos vamos a hacer el trabajo.
englishTranslation: We have an agreement, both of us are going to do the job.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Tenerte aquí conmigo es un problema.
englishTranslation: To have you here with me is a problem.

spanishExample: Tienes que hacer ese trabajo con cuidado.
englishTranslation: You have to do that job carefully.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes que tener cuidado cuando lo hagas, no *we want* problemas.
englishTranslation: You have to be careful when you do it, we don’t want trouble.
vocabIncluded: tener cuidado: "to be careful" (idiom, lit. "to have carefulness")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
